content:
The "Systemic Risk Designation Improvement Act of 2016" amends the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act by revising the table of contents and enhancing the authority to supervise and regulate certain nonbank financial companies and bank holding companies. The Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act is amended to enhance supervision and regulation of certain nonbank financial companies and bank holding companies. The Dodd-Frank Act allows the Council to determine if a bank holding company should be subject to enhanced supervision and prudential standards by the Board of Governors if it poses a threat to the financial stability of the United States. The Council uses the Basel Committee's indicator-based approach to determine systemic importance of bank holding companies based on size, interconnectedness, substitutes availability, global activity, and complexity. Some GSIBs may be designated by law for enhanced supervision. The subsection outlines that a bank holding company designated as a Global Systemically Important Bank by the Financial Stability Board will be considered to have undergone a final determination. The text chunk discusses amendments to various subsections in the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform Act related to the designation of bank holding companies and nonbank financial companies. The changes include redefining terms and adjusting references within the sections. Amendments to the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform Act include redefining terms and adjusting references within sections related to the designation of bank holding companies. Amendments to the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform Act involve changes to sections related to the designation of bank holding companies, including adjustments to references in subsections of section 113 and modifications to sections 116, 121, and 155. Amendments to the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform Act include changes to section 155 regarding the Office of Financial Research, specifically in subsection (d) by replacing the criteria for designation with a final determination under section 113. SEC. 4. REVISIONS TO BOARD AUTHORITY. The Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform Act is amended to remove the threshold of $50,000,000,000 for certain provisions and replace it with a final determination under section 113. This includes changes to acquisitions, management interlocks, and enhanced supervision and prudential standards. This includes changes to acquisitions, management interlocks, and enhanced supervision and prudential standards. Amendments are made to subsections of section 113 and a conforming amendment is made to section 11 of the Federal Reserve Act. Amendments to section 11 of the Federal Reserve Act include redesignating subsections and changing the threshold for financial institutions subject to final determinations under section 113 of the Dodd-Frank Act. SEC. 5. EFFECTIVE DATE; RULE OF APPLICATION.

The Financial Stability Oversight Council can initiate proceedings for a bank holding company under section 113(c)(1) of the Dodd-Frank Act upon enactment of this Act. A final determination cannot be made within one year of enactment. Large bank holding companies with assets over $50,000,000,000 will be subject to immediate application during this period.

SEC. 6. EXISTING ASSESSMENT TERMINATION SCHEDULE. Each bank holding company with total consolidated assets equal to or greater than $50,000,000,000 will be subject to assessments by the Secretary of the Treasury, limited to a total of $115,000,000. Assessments will be expedited if necessary to reach the total amount. The Secretary of the Treasury will collect $115,000,000 in assessments before fiscal year 2018, with payment options spread out or as a one-time payment. These assessments are in addition to any other required by law. $60,000,000 will be transferred to the Financial Stability Oversight Council for administrative costs. The Stability Oversight Council will distribute $20,000,000 each to the Federal Reserve System, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, and the Treasury. Additionally, $55,000,000 will be transferred to the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation for resolution costs. Bank holding companies assessed under this section will no longer be subject to assessments if they receive a final determination under the Dodd-Frank Act. Bank holding companies assessed under this section will not receive refunds for prior payments. If a bank holding company is deemed to have a final determination under the Dodd-Frank Act, they will not be subject to assessments solely by operation of that section. SEC. 7. RULE OF CONSTRUCTION. This Act does not broadly apply international standards, except as specified in section 113(c) of the Dodd-Frank Act.
